bestBHT.bht: On this day, Paul solemnly testifies that he is pure from the blood of all men. He appeals to the witness of his hearers, charging them that if any of them are lost, the fault lies not with him but with themselves. Through his faithful preaching and teaching, he has discharged his duty and cannot be held responsible for their ruin. However, he humbly acknowledges that if anyone perishes, it is not due to his own guilt, but rather the consequences of their own choices.

Jamieson-Fausset-Brown: from the blood of all men— ( :-; and compare 1 Samuel 12:3;
Albert Barnes: If any of you are lost; if you prove unfaithful to God, I appeal to yourselves that the fault is not mine.

Ministers who preach the gospel with fidelity may thus appeal to their hearers; and in the day of judgment may call on themselves to witness that the fault of the ruin of the soul is not to be charged to them.
He had discharged his duty in faithfully warning and teaching them; and now, if they were lost, the fault would be their own, not his.
Marvin Vincent: This day [τη σημερον ημερα] . Very forcible. Lit., on today's day; this, our parting day.
John Calvin: Let them leave that to God alone to be ordered at his pleasure. So shall it come to pass that the inventions of men shall have none entrance into the Church of God.

Mortal man shall not be so bold as to mangle the Scripture and to pull it in pieces, that he may diminish − this or that at his pleasure, that he may obscure something and suppress many things; but shall deliver whatsoever is revealed in the Scripture, though wisely and seasonably for the edifying of the people, yet plainly and without guile.

I do not doubt but that he had respect unto the place of Ezekiel, where God denounceth that his prophet shall be guilty of the blood of the wicked unless he exhort them unto repentance. For upon this condition doth he appoint pastors over his Church, that if anything perish through their negligence, an account may be required at their hands.
Philip Schaff: Wherefore I take you to record this day, that I am pure from the blood of all men.
His ceaseless, self-denying labours among the people at Ephesus would at least free him from that blood-guiltiness.
If any man perishes, I am not myself guilty.
Archibald T. Robertson: I testify (μαρτυρομα). Elsewhere in the N.T. only in Paul's Epistles (Galatians 5:3; Ephesians 4:17; 1 Thessalonians 2:12). It means 'I call to witness' while μαρτυρεω means 'I bear witness.'
This day (εν τη σημερον ημερα). The today day, the last day with you, our parting day.

I am pure from the blood of all men (καθαρος ειμ απο του αιματος παντων). Paul was sensitive on this point as in Corinth (Acts 18:6). It is much for any preacher to claim and it ought to be true of all. The papyri also give this use of απο with the ablative rather than the mere ablative after καθαρος.
John Gill: I am pure from the blood of all men.
They could only bear a testimony for him with respect to themselves.
The ruin and destruction of no one of them could be laid to his charge.

bhtAttempts.bht: On this day, Paul calls upon his hearers to bear witness that he is innocent of their blood, echoing the sentiment found in 1 Samuel, Ezekiel, and the Apostle Paul's other letters. His ministry has been marked by faithfulness, as he testifies, and he declares that he is free from the guilt of their potential loss. By discharging his duty to faithfully preach and teach, he absolves himself from any responsibility for their spiritual fate. Yet he acknowledges that if anyone perishes, it is not due to his own fault but rather their own refusal to heed the Gospel message.

On this day, Paul solemnly testifies that he is pure from the blood of all men. He appeals to the witness of his hearers, charging them that if any of them are lost, the fault lies not with him but with themselves. Through his faithful preaching and teaching, he has discharged his duty and cannot be held responsible for their ruin. However, he humbly acknowledges that if anyone perishes, it is not due to his own guilt, but rather the consequences of their own choices.

Paul declares on this day that he is innocent of the blood of all men, calling on himself as a witness. He has faithfully fulfilled his duty of preaching and teaching, absolving himself from any blame if any should perish. The fault, he emphasizes, lies with the individuals themselves if they choose to reject the message. While he does not claim personal guilt for their ruin, his earnest plea is a reminder of the great responsibility and accountability that comes with being a messenger of the Gospel.

On this day, Paul testifies that he is pure from the blood of all men, appealing to his hearers as witnesses. If any are lost, he asserts that the fault does not lie with him. Through his faithful ministry of warning and teaching, he has discharged his duty and cannot be held responsible for their ruin. Yet Paul acknowledges that if anyone perishes, it is not due to his own guilt but rather their own choices and actions.

On this day of parting, I testify that I am pure from the blood of all men. I call upon you to bear witness that if any of you are lost, it is not because of any fault of mine. I have faithfully discharged my duty in warning and teaching you. Therefore, the fault of any soul that is ruined will not be charged to me. My ceaseless labors among you have freed me from any guilt. I am not myself guilty if any man perishes.
